text: <@U13TWBRBL>, <@U0PB67X4K>: if you have 2 byzantine nodes in a 4-node network, it doesn't imply that consensus doesn't make progress.  consensus can make progress (depending on what the byzantine nodes do), but your correctness is no longer guaranteed.  In other words, the colluding byzantine nodes could craft an alternate blockchain development (and even history, to some degree) and accuse the other two (actually correct) replicas of colluding.  No way to tell the difference.

Critical dev ops item came up in Identity WG yesterday and in the face2face general session today - "Fiduciary Code" -  review and promotion of the code base releases probably ought to be locked down and signed via electronic signatures and entitlements and perhaps its own blockchain - this is crucial basis for eating own dog food and tamperproofing - audit/compliance/legal review-friendly items needs to start with the code base, runtime crypto and logging is not sufficient

Related to "Fiduciary Code" are "Fiduciary Events". Runtime events like a smart contract that evals to false needs to be recorded in the blockchain for non-repudiation purposes. Likewise, voting a validator node in or out has business / regulatory implications, so should also be recorded on the block.
<@U14KZA474>: waht does "a smart contract that evals to false" mean?  Just want to get clarity ....
i.e., transaction that is validated / confirmed or not (e.g., signatures are valid or if they are not)
aha.  ok, so you mean a submitted tran, that wasn't validated.  gotit.  indeed, we agree.
Ram suggested that these items be added as use cases (or possibly requirements) to begin with so they get fed into the project's process
Added to wiki as use cases
<!channel>: I created <#C16S9A60L> channel to facilitate contributors requesting an invite to the GitHub hyperledger org

<!channel> I recovered two items: one is a hat, the other a notebook. If one is yours, please send me a message describing the item and let’s arrange to return it to you. They’re both fairly distinct. Also, thank you for making the f2f a great success!
thanks <@U0UHG4VP1> and <@U0J038AJK> and DTCC for hosting a great F2F
next month we'll try left coast .. soliciting volunteer hosts - IBM could possibly host in south San Jose... SF might be better for some... let me or <@U0PTU8XN3> or <@U0J038AJK> know if interested
